node.title: Time running out for 10-metre sperm whale stranded on Flinders Island
node.description: Conservation experts are attending to a sperm whale stranded off the coast of northern Tasmania â€” but an expert has warned the species are "not the easiest to refloat".
node.content:
["Conservation experts are attending to a sperm whale stranded off the coast of northern Tasmania \u2014 but an expert has warned the species are \"not the easiest to refloat\".", "The animal was spotted on Sunday\u00a0on North East River beach near Stanley lighthouse, on Flinders\u00a0Island.", "Maree Barber posted a photo of the whale just after 1pm on Monday, adding that it was \"still alive\" but there was \"no one here to help\".", "Tasmania's Marine Conservation Program are investigating.", "A Department of Primary Industries, Water and Environment spokesperson said marine rescue volunteers, wildlife biologists, Tasmanian parks and wildlife service staff and a vet were on the scene and keeping the whale comfortable.", "", "
Dr Vanessa Pirotta said\u00a0the longer whales remain\u00a0on land, \"the less likely they are to survive\".(Facebook: Dr Vanessa Pirotta)
", "The sperm whale is estimated to weigh 12 tonnes and is about 10 metres long.", "Marine scientist\u00a0Vanessa Pirotta said unlike other types of whales, the sperm whale doesn't undertake an annual migration journey.\u00a0", "Dr\u00a0Pirotta said \"this whale may've just been passing through in deep waters and has unfortunately run into a bit of trouble\".", "In September 2021, about 270 pilot whales became stranded on a sandbar near Strahan, about 190 kilometres from Hobart on Tasmania's west coast.", "While it is unclear what caused the male sperm whale to become stranded, there are several plausible explanations, Dr Pirotta said.", "\"The animal could've been ill, the animal may have been swimming and was struck by a vessel, or the animal may have navigated too close to land and as a result has become stranded.\"", "While every effort is being made to try and save the whale, Dr Pirotta\u00a0said \"this is not the easiest of animals to refloat\".", "While seeing a stranded whale can be distressing, Dr Pirotta said researchers learn from the event.", "\"Especially for an animal like the sperm whale which dives to the depths of the ocean, which is two to three kilometres deep, this will be an opportunity to learn more about this remarkable animal.\"", "Authorities ask that if members of the public see a stranded whale or dolphin (alive or dead), they report it to the Marine Conservation Program on 0427 WHALES (0427 942537)."]
